Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Two phenotypes, one genome: genomic conflict as a research framework for professional development of science educators
Award.AbstractNarration:
Genomic conflict occurs when different organisms must be produced from the same set of genes, akin to building different structures from the same set of blueprints. A common example is the production of males and females from the shared genome of a species. Conflict arises because genes that are evolutionarily favored in males are disfavored in females, and vice versa. If these conflicts are difficult to resolve, then they will have profound impacts on the evolution of most species. However, the basic question of how to produce two different organisms from the same set of genes transcends evolutionary biology because it involves every step along the way from the expression of genes to the hormones that regulate the development of each sex. This research will provide fundamental insights into the relationship between the genome and the phenotype, along with significant training of K-12 teachers in cutting-edge science.

This project has three goals: (1) use new sequencing technology to measure the amount of genomic conflict in a wild population of a lizard in which males and females are so different that they are often mistaken for separate species, (2) test whether this conflict is mitigated by a recently discovered phenomenon in which females appear to adaptively bias the sex of their offspring, and (3) combine breeding experiments with the latest methods for simultaneously measuring the expression of thousands of individual genes to test whether sex differences in hormone levels can reduce genome-wide conflict. This research will support a new professional development program for high school science teachers from underserved schools, who will work alongside project personnel and a national network of collaborators in science and education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Genomic conflict occurs because natural selection favors different traits in males and females, yet both sexes share a single genome that must evolve in response to these different demands.

 

The first goal of this project was to explore the dynamics of this conflict as they naturally occur a wild population. One key outcome was the development of a new genetic technique that permits the rapid and accurate assignment of parentage (genetic identification of mother and father) for thousands of individual offspring produced by hundreds of adult males and females each year on a single island population, using only a small DNA sample. When combined with detailed records of individual survival across four time points per year, then layered across five successive generations, this genetic technique has produced a dataset for which total lifetime fitness (total number of offspring produced, from birth until death) is known for thousands of individuals. This study has shown that natural selection acts differently on males and females for a variety of traits. It has also shown that males have much higher variation in fitness than do females. In other words, the majority of males that are born will father zero offspring, while some males eventually father 30, 40, or even 50 offspring. This means that natural selection has the potential to act more strongly on males than on females.

 

The second goal of this project was to understand how the shared genome of males and females has evolved to relax this genomic conflict. A key discovery is that the hormone testosterone, which naturally circulates at much higher levels in males than in females, is responsible for relaxing the genetic constraint between the sexes. Although males and females share the same genes, their divergent hormone profiles produce dramatic differences in body size and ornamentation. What this project has added is the first demonstration that hormones actually change the ways in which traits are genetically correlated with one another. Most importantly, testosterone reduces the extent to which traits are genetically correlated between males and females. This means that natural selection can, in principle, act on genetic variation in one sex that is largely independent of genetic variation in the other sex. The different hormonal environments of males and females should therefore allow the sexes to respond more independently to the different selection pressures that they experience in the wild.

 

The third goal of this project was to create Evolution Education - a new model for professional development of K-12 teachers that emphasizes hands-on activities for teaching evolution and for conducting novel experiments in the classroom. Over the duration of the award, over 60 science teachers (primarily from middle school and high school) participated in one of 5 annual Evolution Education professional development workshops focused on presenting hands-on activities for teaching science, engaging with live plants and animals, connecting with scientists, and designing innovative curriculum. Ten exceptional teachers from across the country were selected as 2-year Teacher Fellows. These Fellows attended additional workshops on Current Evolution and Curriculum Design, traveled to participate in field research in Florida with grant personnel (as in the first goal, above), and designed their own unique experiments that they conducted with their home classrooms (on topics ranging from cockroach personality and sex differences in mosquito development to the consumption and degradation of plastic and styrofoam by waxworms and mealworms and the tensile properties of spider silk). Several key outcomes included 1) a peer-reviewed publication in Behavioral Ecology co-authored by high school teachers, University of Virginia undergraduates, and grant personnel, 2) presentation of a novel high school classroom experiment by a Teacher Fellow at the annual Evolution conference, and 3) development of two "Data Nuggets" online classroom exercises featuring research in this proposal, which are freely available to classrooms around the world. A website was developed to share Evolution Education updates and classroom exercises with the K-12 educational community, and the annual summer workshops are an ongoing resources that the PI intends to continue along with collaborators in science and education.
